meeting_annotations.speaker: nathaniel gabor (UC Riverside)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I would not want to be the one responsible for taking the, you know, the the the single like data point to the New York Times. I don't think that would feel very good.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shawn Domagal-Goldman (he/him) - NASA
meeting_annotations.transcript: it's a brief point but that depends on the on the how how common life is, right?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Dan Huber (he/him, University of Hawaii)
meeting_annotations.transcript: If it's rare then you look for the one outlier, if it's common, you can actually look for it.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shawn Domagal-Goldman (he/him) - NASA
meeting_annotations.transcript: I I I want to just make one note here because it's some it's related to something that that is um been part of some other discussions I've been in that I think will have more publicly soon, which is that um the I I almost think of this in kind of like two two stages like we're whatever we do, uh we're going to have that moment with the New York Times and the press conference and stuff like that. The challenging thing will be I I don't think there's any I I I realistically don't think there's a standard that we're going to be able to meet where we know for certain that we're at that moment when that press conference happens. I think it's almost certainly going to be we found something interesting, we think it is life, we're comfortable saying it it is in a paper, but like the real test is going to be whether or not that discovery holds up 50 years later after a bunch of postdocs and grad students question and we probably send a follow up mission to wherever we thought we found it. Um, so I think like that that both means that I don't think we should ever hold ourselves to the standard that like it has to be either absolutely we found it or like let's not do it. It can be part of some progressive build up of a case and also it it thinking of it that way is like the start of a longer term investigation opens up some longer term studies of a planet. You know, we one mission as G pointed out in the chat's only going to cover five to 10 years, maybe 20. Um, but it's probably not the last mission we would send especially if we saw something interesting. So, you know, this could be a century's long experiment that just starts up just like any form of of exploration or or observation.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Timothy W. Lyons
meeting_annotations.transcript: Let me just layer on that before we go to the hands because I think that's exactly right and that's what often comes up in conversations when I press people. They say if we find O2 around a planet that's not around an M star where it's easy to attribute to to false positives, O2 around a terrestrial planet in a habitable zone around a G star, that's a headline in its own regard. That's going to be really, really exciting. And the knack or the trick for us is to be able to present that as a huge step forward without being definitive proof. I think that's not that hard to do. The other thing also the techno signature discussion is is really interesting. There are people who argue against that because if you look at our own planet, that's 60 years of 4.1 billion years of life history. Um, and when I query audiences about whether they'd be excited if we discover methane around a planet that within 90% certainty is related to biology, would they be excited and they always say yes. They always say yes. So I think, you know, the world is primed for anything that's somewhat convincing. Should we let's go to hands. I don't know who's next.
